Since  1993  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  been  assisting  the  Government  of  Sri

for  approval,  the  Government  is  taking  steps  to  establish  an  apex  water  resources  management

3.
Following up on these activities and in support of the enhanced management of the country's
water  resources,  the  Government  has  requested  further  assistance  to  help  set  up  the  apex  water

management infrastructure. In response to this request, ADB Fact-Finding and Appraisal Missions4

BACKGROUND

4.
Sri Lanka is an island nation with limited water resources and an ever-increasing demand on
them.  From 1971 to 1998, the country's population increased from 12.6 million to 18.8 million, with
no  concomitant  increase  in  the  water  resource.  Indeed,  gross  water  availability  declined  over  the
same  period  due  to  pollution,  watershed  degradation,  increasing  seasonal  variability,  seawater
intrusion into rivers, and the unsustainable extraction of groundwater.

5.
During the same period, urban areas as well as industrial growth expanded dramatically and
tourism  became  an  important  earner  of  foreign  exchange  so  that  the  locational  and  geographic
demand for water changed as significantly as the overall quantum demand.  In other words, water

6.
Most sectors of the Sri Lankan economy are heavily dependent on water. Among them are
agriculture, industry, power, fisheries, the commercial sector and tourism. None of them can perform
to optimum efficiency in an environment of uncertain and restricted water use. Indeed, in the past 30
years  almost  all  sectors  of  the  economy  in  Sri  Lanka  rapidly  expanded.  Without  water  resources,
that expansion would not have been possible.  Expansion in agriculture has been achieved through
major increases in the use of water for irrigation.  Increased use of hydropower has been the basis
of growth in manufacturing and the service sectors. A major increase in the use of river water and
groundwater  has  allowed  an  expansion  of  urban  areas  and  growth  in  manufacturing  and  tourism.
The country's rivers have supplied the sand required in large quantities as a construction material for
the country's recent building boom.

7.
Although Sri Lanka's total water supplies are abundant compared with those in some more
arid  countries,5  water  stress  is  now  being  experienced,  and  regional  and  seasonal  variations  in
supply and demand already create problems. One reason is that the country has a very high  year-
to-year  rainfall  variability  as  well  as  high  locational  and  seasonal  variation.  Another  is  the  fact  that
the quantum growth in water use over the past 30 years has been far greater than that envisaged
during the planning of each individual water development project or scheme.

8.
The country's vulnerability was seen in 1996 when drought conditions caused a substantial
shortfall  in  paddy  production;  disrupted  hydropower  production,  leading  to  island-wide  power  cuts;
and forced several urban water supply systems to shut down. Stress on the country's water supplies
is also seen in the increasing salinity intrusion into rivers emptying into the sea; the number of urban
water supply systems suffering from chronic, and occasionally acute, water shortages; and delays in
new domestic water supply investments because of uncertain water availability.

A  major  reason  for  the  worsening  water  supply  situation  despite  the  rather  plentiful  overall

supplies is the fact that, traditionally, water was considered an abundant resource readily available
for  all,  and  was  always  exploited  as  such.  Irrigation  accounts  for  some  80  percent  of  water
consumption and has always been provided free of any significant charge. The overuse of irrigation
water  is  common  and  paddy  is  sometimes  grown  on  unsuitable,  sandy  soils,  while  downstream
users  may  not  have  sufficient  water  for  their  own  irrigation  or  domestic  use  requirements.
Hydropower reservoirs now provide a major part of the country's electricity needs, yet the timing of
hydropower  releases  does  not  necessarily  coincide  with  the  peak  requirements  for  agriculture  or
domestic  use.  Groundwater  has  been  considered  a  resource  available  for  anyone  who  has  the
wherewithal  to  pump  it.  As  a  result,  urban  water  supply  schemes  and  new  industries  extract
groundwater  without  any  control  or  consideration  of  the  recharge  capacity.    Moreover,  any  water
body is liable to be used as a convenient conveyance for factory or domestic sewage discharge, so
there is little restraint on the release of effluents into drainage ditches and water bodies. Even the
sand in riverbeds is considered free for all and has been extensively mined in recent years to supply
the construction needs of a building boom.  This use has altered river morphology to such an extent
that  high  and  low  flow  patterns  completely  differ  from  historical  patterns,  and  saline  water
increasingly  intrudes  into  river  mouths.  Consequently,  domestic  water  supply  facilities  are
endangered, while reduced flows and pollution are endangering sensitive wildlife habitats.

12.
To  remedy  the  situation  and  to  begin  managing  Sri  Lanka's  water  as  a  scarce  resource
rather than a freely available public commodity, there is an overriding need for an agency or body
with  the  authority  to  manage  the  country's  water  resources  on  a  global  or  holistic  basis.  The
establishment of such an apex agency and the passage of legislation to provide it with meaningful
powers are the major recommendations of the TA for Institutional Strengthening for Comprehensive

13.
The  consequences  of  poor  water  management  are  felt  most  severely  by  the  poorer
segments  of  the  country's  population.  As  the  competition  for  water  increases,  reduced  availability
combined  with  deteriorating  quality  is  posing  serious  problems  to  public  health  and  further
development  activities.  The  poor  have  the  least  ready  access  to  safe,  potable  water  for  domestic
use. They can least afford medical care after becoming ill from contaminated water, suffer most from
reduced  incomes  due  to  deficient  irrigation  water  supplies,  and  suffer  most  from  lost  employment
opportunities when industries cannot be established due to inadequate water supplies or unresolved
water use conflicts.

B.

Government Policies and Plans

As noted in paras. 10 and 11, current Government policies have traditionally focused on the
14.
management of water resources on an agency-by-agency basis and have been generally designed
to  maximize  the  operational  benefits  of  a  particular  agency  within  its  particular  mandate.  For
example, the ID focuses on maximizing water use for irrigation, while NWSDB focuses on providing
the  maximum  domestic  water  supply  possible  to  the  largest  possible  number  of  users.  In  some
cases,  the  different  emphasis  may  entail  policies  aimed  at  water  conservation  or  efficient  use,  but
generally the aim is to make available greater supplies within the same sector. Thus, programs for
more efficient use of irrigation water are generally focused on making more water available for other
irrigators, and programs aimed at reducing leakage and increasing cost recovery in domestic water
supply schemes are primarily focused on conserving water so as to expand coverage.

15.
In  other  cases,  policies  being  pursued  by  Government  agencies  are  even  potentially  (or
actively) inimical to the conservation and rational use of water resources.  Agriculture development
programs  and  preferential  credit  schemes  that  promote  the  use  of  tubewells  or  low-lift  pumps  for
irrigation are being undertaken without regard for the availability or sustainability of groundwater or
river  water  resources.  Industrial  estate  developments  are  being  pursued  without  adequate
consideration  of  the  need  for  freshwater  nor  the  need  to  dispose  of  effluents.  Some  government
contracts require the use of clean, sorted river sand for construction projects. The result is excessive
sand mining in the country’s rivers.

Integrated water resource management is, however, not completely unknown or unpracticed

water  supply,  and  actively  encourages  water  conservation  measures  among  the  farmers  in  its

requirements, inland fisheries, groundwater, or the environmental aspects of water use.

work  out  water  use  conflicts.  However,  any  interagency  agreement  is  nonbinding  and  depends  on
the goodwill of one agency toward another.

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

42. When Sri Lanka had a predominantly rural, agrobased economy with few industries and only
a limited urban population, integrated water resource management was not a pressing issue. Water
was  used  primarily  for  irrigation  or  domestic  rural  supply,  and  competing  demands  for  other  uses
were  easily  accommodated.  In  the  more  recent  past,  however,  this  picture  has  changed
dramatically.  Rapid industrial growth has led to major additional demands, and the growth of urban
areas throughout the country has raised the water requirements in areas and locations where they
were  traditionally  much  more  modest.  Moreover,  the  development  of  intensive  cropping  has  led  to
increased water demand in the agriculture sector.

43.
As  a  result,  while  the  country  does  not  face  a  water  management  crisis,  there  are  signs  of
increasing stress on  the water resource and competition between users. The increasing degree of
competition and stress are occurring while climatic variability, watershed degradation, and pollution
are  threatening  the  water  resource  itself.  In  some  areas,  the  combination  of  low  water  availability
and  poor  quality  of  the  supply  is  a  constraint  to  further  development  and  is  causing  public  health
problems. As pointed out in para. 13, the impact is most severe on the poor.

B.  

Objective and Scope

48.
The objective of the Project is to strengthen the Government's capacity to manage its water
resources  in  a  sustainable,  transparent,  and  participatory  way,  and  to  mitigate  the  effects  of  past
uncoordinated  water  resource  use.  This  objective  will  contribute  to  the  overall  sector  goal  of  the
Project to establish the sustainable management of water resources through the implementation of a
national water policy under adequate institutional arrangements. The Project will comprise two parts:
(i)  capacity  building  designed  to  assist  in  the  establishment  of  NWRA  and  the  strengthening  of
existing  agencies  in  the  water  sector  (part  A),  and  (ii)  the  construction  of  urgently  needed  water

Establishment of the National Water Resources Authority

b.

Database Improvement

51.
Data  on  the  water  resource  in  Sri  Lanka  is  patchy,  often  outdated,  and  unreliable  due  to
recent  environmental  changes  from  activities  such  as  sand  mining.  It  is  also  difficult  to  assemble
since  it  is  collected  and  held  by  a  number  of  separate  agencies.  Under  these  circumstances,  any
meaningful management and planning activities are difficult to carry out.

52.
Data for surface water is the most readily available, but may be unreliable due to the age of
the monitoring system and the great number of environmental changes that have taken place in the
past  few  decades.    Data  for  groundwater  is  sparse,  except  in  certain  well-defined  and  restricted
areas, so that little is known about the overall groundwater resource of the country. Similarly, except
in certain specific locations, data on water quality as a time series is almost nonexistent.

management, and sharing of data and information for surface water, groundwater, and water quality.
For  surface  water  the  activities  will  consist  of  (i)  the  provision  and  establishment  of  modernized
gauging  stations,  (ii)  the  provision  of  hydrometric  equipment,  and  (iii)  the  provision  of  data
management equipment as well as transport facilities for the data collection staff.19 For groundwater
the activities involve (i) the sinking of measurement wells, (ii) the provision of measuring instruments
and data management equipment, and (iii) training in their installation and use. For water quality the
activities will consist of upgrading laboratories and equipment for water quality testing. A centralized
database will be established in WRS/NWRA, using modern software and information technology to
facilitate data sharing.

2.

Infrastructure for Water Resource Management (Part B)

63.
Part B will be of the construction of the Kelani Conservation Barrage for water level control
near  the  intake  for  the  Colombo  water  supply  treatment  plant  at  Ambatale  together  with  the
construction of low-flow measuring weirs, including one on the Kelani River to guide the operation of
the barrage.

a.

Kelani Conservation Barrage

The barrage will have an adjustable crest that can be raised and lowered to control the water
64.
level at the treatment plant intake.  This need arises because the progressive lowering of the river
levels due to excessive sand mining and the decline of river discharges in recent times has caused
the  intake  of  saline  water  by  the  plant  and  reduced  the  extraction  rates  due  to  lower  pumping
efficiency.  The  barrage  will  enable  water  levels  to  be  raised  and  maintained  at  the  original  design
levels during the dry season. It will thus restore the original pumping capacity and also prevent the
intake of saline water. In practice, the crest of the barrage will be raised only at critical times of the
year, when low flows in the months between February and May could otherwise mean disruption in
the  water  supply  due  to  low  water  levels  and  saline  intrusion.  As  an  adjustable  structure  used
sparingly and at critical times when contamination of the city's water supply looks imminent, it will not
normally interfere with either the flows or the use of the river. Without the barrage, the ever-present
danger  is  that  the  water  supply  to  the  whole  of  Greater  Colombo  (nearly  2  million  persons,
thousands  of  businesses,  and  hundreds  of  industries)  could  be  severely  reduced  or  cut  off  for
several days at a time. The only viable alternatives that could be completed within the urgent time
frame  are  (i)  to  move  the  intake  and  water  treatment  plant  further  upstream;  (ii)  to  pump  from  a
neighboring basin, at considerable expense; or (iii) to operate upstream hydropower reservoirs and
consumptive  water  diversions  to  significantly  increase  flows  in  the  lower  river.  All  of  these
alternatives would involve significantly higher costs.

b.

Low-Flow Weirs

65.
This component will finance the installation of small, fixed-crest weirs to allow accurate and
reliable  measurement  of  low  flows  in  critical  rivers  at  critical  times.  This  is  essential  for  effective
management  of  the  water  resources,  and  for  the  effective  operation  of  the  Kelani  Conservation
Barrage during the dry season. Provision is made for the installation of six low-flow weirs at various
locations  in  the  western  rivers  around  Colombo.  Although  they  are  relatively  expensive,  the  weirs
provide a definite and secure solution for achieving accurate measurement of low flows by stabilizing
otherwise  variable  river  conditions.  It  is  recognized  that  cheaper  nonstructural  solutions  requiring
regular flow measurements at short intervals may be appropriate at some sites instead of the weirs,
or  there  may  be  more  efficient  sites  for  the  weirs.  Hence  the  program  will  be  reviewed  in  further
detail during implementation and the Executing Agency and ADB will agree on modifications prior to
implementation.

Social Dimensions

111.
The social impact of the project will, in the short term, be either neutral or very minor (para.
103).  The  long-term  social  impact  will,  however,  be  significant.  Most  issues  in  water  use  are
ultimately social. Conflicts in water use are primarily conflicts between the use of water by one group
of  people  and  the  use  of  water  by  another  (or  even  the  demand  for  different  uses  by  the  same
group).  The  conflicts  may  be  manifested  in  the  need  for  domestic  water  versus  the  need  for
irrigation; the need for watershed protection versus the need for upland dwellers to grow food crops
and make a living; and the need for garbage and sewage disposal versus the need for fresh drinking
water. Planning water use thus entails, to a large extent, the resolution of conflicting or competing

Impact on Poverty

26

112.
The existence of a functioning water resources apex group, along with a mechanism to allow
consultation in water allocation, will provide the poorer segments of society with the forum needed to
enunciate their water resource needs and to ensure that, to some extent, these needs are met.  In
real  terms,  both  the  rural  and  the  urban  poor  will  have  a  voice  in  determining  their  access  to  a
resource essential to their physical and economic well-being and advancement.

113. About  one  fifth  of  Sri  Lanka’s  population  is  categorized  as  poor  on  the  basis  of  an  income
threshold of about SLRs720 or $10.1 per person per month. The income is still highly skewed, with
the bottom 20 percent of the income earners receiving less than 4 percent, while the top 20 percent
receive about 55 percent of the total income. While unemployment in the country is relatively high
(8.5 percent in 1999), underemployment is more closely linked with poverty. The majority of the poor
are working in low-productivity occupations in agriculture and fisheries, and 80 percent of them are
to  be  found  in  the  rural  areas.  Poverty  is  prevalent  in  the  three  pilot  river  basins:  Menik  Ganga,
Deduru Oya, and Attanagalu Oya. Since water-related problems are limiting the productivity of the
rural dwellers, the Project is likely to have an indirect poverty reduction impact in providing water of
adequate quality and a reliable supply, especially for small farmers.

114.
The  Kelani  Conservation  Barrage  will  improve  water  supply  in  the  Greater  Colombo  area
where  problems  of  supply  interruption  and  low  pressure  exist  mostly  in  areas  of  low-income
households in the shantytowns and slums. The socioeconomic profiles of the benefited areas show
that almost half of the population are beneficiaries of the Government’s Samurdhi Social Safety Net
program, which targets people below the poverty line. Most of the residents rely on communal stand
posts  for  water,  with  40-200  households  sharing  one  stand  post.  After  the  construction  of  the
barrage,  NWSDB  will  be  able  to  extend  and  enhance  the  water  supply  service  in  these  areas.
Communal  stand  posts  will  provide  more  reliable  supplies,  and  there  will  be  an  option  for  private
connections. Hence, the quality of life will be enhanced for some 330,000 beneficiaries, and almost
half of them are below the poverty line. The barrage will particularly benefit the poorer women in the
target area who walk and carry water from a distance ranging from 60 to 900 meters. In addition, the
construction of the barrage and the low-flow weirs will create temporary employment for more than
100 persons.

A.

Water Resources Policy Foundation

1.
A  number  of  warning  signs  point  to  increasing  water  resource  problems  in  Sri  Lanka.
Competition  and  water  shortages  will  increase  as  a  result  of  a  highly  variable  rainfall  and  a
growing  demand  for  water.  The  degradation  of  watersheds  is  resulting  in  sedimentation  of
reservoirs and more serious floods and droughts.  Water pollution from domestic, agricultural, and
industrial  sources  is  contaminating  surface  water  and  groundwater  and  affecting  public  health.
Groundwater  is  being  overextracted  in  some  areas,  affecting  its  availability  to  others  and  for
environmental values.

2.

economic, and environmental needs of present and future generations. Additional objectives are

D.

Groundwater Management

12.
Groundwater  is  widely  used  for  domestic,  small-scale  irrigation,  industrial,  and  other
purposes  in  Sri  Lanka.  There  are  many  types  of  shallow  and  deep  groundwater  aquifers;  each
has  its  own  characteristics  and  management  needs.  In  addition  to  providing  a  ready  source  of
water for consumptive purposes, shallow aquifers play an important role in discharging water to
rivers  and  other  water  bodies  during  low  flow  periods.  They  also  support  wetlands  and  native
vegetation.

13.
The  major  groundwater  issues  relate  to  the  fact  that  groundwater  is  essentially  an
unregulated resource. Ownership and management responsibilities for it are not clearly defined.
Although  studies  have  been  conducted  and  well-drilling  data  collected,  there  have  been  no
ongoing  monitoring  and  coordinated  information  system  for  groundwater.  Intensive  urban,
industrial,  tourism,  and  other  developments  have  contributed  to  over-use  and  contamination  of
some aquifers. Subsidy programs to promote the development of shallow “agro-wells” have also
resulted  in  heavy  use  of  shallow  groundwater  in  parts  of  North  Central  and  North  Western
Provinces.

14.
The  rate  of  groundwater  replenishment  and  other  distinctive  features  of  aquifers  will  be
taken into account in groundwater planning and management. Its management will take a long-
term  perspective.  Surface  water  and  groundwater,  particularly  in  shallow  aquifers,  are  closely
related resources. They must therefore be managed in an integrated manner. All policies applied
to  surface  water  will  also  apply  to  groundwater  management.  In  areas  where  there  are  special,
urgent groundwater issues, planning and management of groundwater may go ahead without full
river  basin  planning.  Small  users  will  be  exempt  from  the  requirement  to  hold  entitlements,  but
local  governments  will  be  encouraged  to  register  small  wells  and  to  apply  guidelines  on  well
density in groundwater management areas. Information on groundwater and water conservation
will be disseminated to groundwater users.

15. Water  resources  data  and  information  are  needed  for  effective  water  resource
management.  The  essential  information  includes  policy  development  and  planning,  water
management operations, project planning, public awareness and education, and the investment

Description of the Project

This SIEE is a summary of the potential environmental impacts associated with the Project,

2.
The Project is designed to improve the management of water resources in Sri Lanka. It will
be  implemented  in  two  parts.  Part  A  will  support  the  implementation  of  policy  and  institutional
reforms that the Government has recently approved, which include setting up a new apex body, the
National Water Resource Authority (NWRA). Capacity will be build in the NWRA to undertake its day
to day operations and fulfil its mandate of managing the country’s water resources. This will include
establishing  linkages  with  other  relevant  agencies  in  the  water  sector.  This  will  be  done  through
practical exercises to resolve existing conflicts in three pilot river basins (para 6), thus demonstrating
procedures  for  integrated  river  basin  management.  Part  B  will  construct  infrastructure  to  improve
water resource management. The major component will be the Kelani Conservation Barrage to be
located in the lower reaches of the Kelani Ganga. It is designed to protect against disruptions to the
water  supply  for  Greater  Colombo  by  preventing  saline  intrusions  to  the  intakes  and  maintaining
acceptable levels in the river to avoid pumping operations being interrupted. A smaller component of
part  B  will  the  installation  of  low-flow  weirs  at  various  points  along  the  main  rivers  to  facilitate
accurate measurement of low flows needed by NWRA for proper management of water allocations,
as well as water quality parameters.

C.

Description of the Environment

3.
The SIEE places emphasis on the Kelani Ganga, the site of the Project’s major infrastructure
component. It is the third largest watershed in Sri Lanka and plays an important role with respect to
the country’s overall economy, since it drains the most fertile land in the wet zone and intercepts the
most populated and economically important part of the country including the capital Colombo. Flows
in Kelani Ganga vary widely, according to the season. Annual flood discharges are typically in the
range of 800-1500 cubic meters (m3) per second. Dry season flows are dominated by hydroelectric
power releases from two reservoirs located near the headwaters of the river. The 1-in-50 year low-
flow in the lower reaches is estimated to average less than 10 m3 per second over a 7-day period.

4.
The water supply intake for Greater Colombo is located at Ambatale, 15 km from the mouth
of  the  Kelani  Ganga.  Although  tidal  amplitudes  at  the  mouth  are  low  (0.8  metres  at  spring  tide),
unacceptably  high  salinity  has  been  detected  at  the  intake.  The  situation  becomes  most  critical
during the dry season months (January to March). In 1992, a prolonged drought meant that regular
releases  from  the  reservoirs  could  not  be  maintained,  and  salinity  levels  at  the  intake  reached
unacceptable levels. A temporary sandbag barrier had to be constructed downstream of the intake
to relieve the situation. Excessive sand mining has also reduced the normal river levels causing the
intake  pumps  for  the  water  supply  to  operate  well  below  optimum  range,  with  total  shut  down
required at times. Although water quality at Ambatale is still well within the standards specified for
drinking water with conventional treatment, data shows a trend of increasing pollutant levels over the
last two decades. These problems will require a comprehensive and long-term solution.

5.
Fishing in the Kelani Ganga is not a major economic activity of the people living adjacent to
the  river.  About  20–25  families  fish  as  a  full  time  income-generating  activity  during  the  first  six
months  of  the  year  in  the  river  estuary.  No  fish  species  that  move  up  the  river  for  spawning  are
found  in  the  Kelani  Ganga,  although  the  giant  fresh  water  prawn  (Macrobrachium rosenbergii)

the  only  component  that  results  in  directly  productive  and  measurable  benefits.  Other
components  have  the  overall  objective  of  building  capacity  for  integrated  water  resource
management,  and  will  have  longer  term  impacts  by  establishing  the  enabling  environment  for
future sector investments.
